Welcome to HTML Everywhere

Introduction

This sample application illustrates a new feature named HTML Everywhere. Prof-UIS doesn't use the DrawText() Win32 API anymore. A new HTML/CSS based engine created from scratch is now used everywhere in Prof-UIS. It can display both HTML and plain text, including bi-directional text transformations for plain text.

HTML features

Most HTML tags and attributes are supported except for the following:

  • Forms and input fields.
  • FRAMESET, FRAME and IFRAME tags.
  • Animated images, video, sound and Flash.
  • Unclosed HTML tags are implemented with respect to HTML 4.01 Specification.

CSS features

Most CSS features are supported except for the following:

  • Conditional CSS.
  • caption-side, font-variant, cursor, direction, empty-cells, page-break-after, page-break-before, page-break-inside, text-layout, text-shadow, text-transform, z-index properties.
  • :lang, :first-child, :first-letter, :first-line pseudo-classes.
  • armenian, georgian, lower-greek types of ordered lists.
  • Bi-directional Unicode text is currently not supported. It's implemented in plain text mode only.

Plain text features

Plain text output is completely supported including most of the DT_*** flags used in the DrawText() Win32 API. Tabbed text output is not supported.

Non-standard features and enhancements

The following list contains non-standard features and enhancements:

  • text-align CSS property supports an additional justifywithlastline value which is similar to the justify value but stretches the text in the last paragraph line.
  • Both HTML and plain text can be rotated 90, 180 and 270 degrees. This is essential for UI elements with vertically aligned parts. As an example consider a vertically docked menu bar, a vertically oriented tab control and a horizontally oriented shortcut list control.
  • Both single line and multiline plain text can be aligned vertically. Win32 does not support multiline text to be aligned vertically.
  • Horizontally oriented content can be drawn using the text output APIs provided by the UxTheme.DLL module available in Windows XP and later Windows versions. That is HTML and plain text can be drawn on DWM glass surfaces in Windows Vista and later versions. For example: ribbon tab items with Office 2010 styles applied in an application running on Windows Vista/7 are drawn using composited text with a glow effect. These tabs can be HTML based and HTML content is painted using a composited glow effect.

What do you also need to know?

The new HTML/CSS/plain text processing engine is used for displaying static content only. It's not a straight replacement for web browsers. All objects referenced inside HTML content like CSS styles and images should be loaded in a global object container before their first use.
